Manx: O SCRIEUDEYR vannee! ta my veean boggoil
English: O Blessed writer! My joyful desire

Manx: Ayns jeeaghyn jeï, lesh coointaghtyn gherjoil
English: In looking back, with happy memories

Manx: As eunys anmey, goaill aym pene y tra;
English: And souful delight, taking time for myself;

Manx: Chammoo jaroodym eh—cha jean dy bra;—
English: Neither will I forget it—I never will;—

Manx: Yn imbagh aalin shen jeh m’aegid meïy[1],
English: That beautiful season of my happy youth,
Notes: [1] meïy—unattested elsewhere – a contraction of maynrey? Or mea ‘luxurient’?

Manx: Cuin va my vea lane soylley, as dyn seïy,
English: When my life was full of joy, and without agitation,

Manx: D'imnea; eisht ’smaanrey lhiam dty skeeayll,
English: Of anxiety; then, how happy I am with your news,

Manx: Soiljagh’ dy baghtall roshtynys dty cheayll,
English: Explaining clearly the attainment of your sense,

Manx: Yn skeeal cha milllsh, as cha meeley roï ;
English: The news so sweet, and so smooth running;

Manx: Feeu v’er ny scrieu, as sth’ill smoo feeu dy lhaïh.
English: Worthy of being written, and still more worth reading,

Manx: Resoon lesh onid as lambaanys dooie ;
English: Reason with innocence and due childishness,

Manx: Coyrt raaue da’n scollag,
English: Giving a warning to the youngster,

Manx: Raaue da’n chendeeaght cooie.
English: A warning suitable for the old.

Manx: Ayns coraa dorragh ’eer myr screuit ta’n ghoo,
English: In a dark voice, even as the word is written,

Manx: Ta coamrey’n ysseree lesh soiljey smoo ;
English: The clothing of knowledge with more explanation,

Manx: Geiyrt da sampleyr ghraioil yn YEESEY noo.
English: Following the loving example of holy JESUS.

Manx: Cha derrym ennym ort — veagh shen dy lioor,
English: I will not name you — that would be enough,

Manx: Dy yientyn floutt, as roost ’oo jeh dty ghloyr.
English: To generate insult, and strip you of your glory.

Manx: Agh ga dy vel mee chionney'r binn yn oaie,
English: But although I am close to the corners of the grave,

Manx: As coontey beg jeh nheeghyn nagh vel chaïee ;
English: And think little of things that are not everlasting,

Manx: Fooast verrym moylley da’n ERTREOLTAGH vie,
English: Yet I praise the good COMPASSIONATE ONE,

Manx: Ta, lesh e choyrle, leeideil yn annym thie.
English: Who, by his counsel, leads my soul home.

Manx: Smooar veagh y foays dauesyn ta seïyt 'sy theihll,
English: How great would be the benefit for those who are agitated in the world,

Manx: Da lioaryn vie yn aegid dy chur geill :
English: To pay attention to good books of youth:

Manx: Yn dooinney prowal ny va’n guilley cre’al,
English: The man proves that which the boy was believing,

Manx: Ayns gerjagh, shee, as boggey, teh partail;
English: In happiness, peace, and joy, he partakes,

Manx: Ayns ynnyd mergey ersyn[2], ghied ersooyl,
English: Instead of corroding him, stealing away,
Notes: [2] mergey ersyn – meaning unclear, could be corroding him.

Manx: Lesh crout y Jouyll,—myr maarlagh
English: With the craft of the Devil, like a thief

Manx: cheet ny chooyl.
English: coming behind him.

Manx: Yn stoyr dy ynrickys va ayns e chree,
English: The store of faithfulness that was in his heart,

Manx: As cleayn’ yn annym beayn veih oghrish sheeant e YEE.
English: And persuades the eternal soul from the holy bosom of his GOD.
